summary: Unit 8 begins with a discussion of the ways organisms respond to the environment. From behavioral to physiological responses, organisms will react to stimuli in their environment to increase their survival or enhance the fitness of their population by communication.

vocab.definition: The modification of actions, activities, and reactions that organisms exhibit in response to stimuli within the environment
Changes in an organismâ€™s functions, processes, or form
A detectable change in an organism's internal or external environment that triggers a response
A physiological reaction that occurs when an individual encounters a perceived threat or danger that prepares the body to either confront the threat or escape it
A message sent from one organism to another that can be visual, audible, chemical, electrical, and tactile
Chemical signals that animals use to communicate within the same species, affecting behaviors like mating, territorial marking, and alarm responses
Behaviors that are genetically programmed, inherited, and occur naturally in all members of a species without the need for learning or practice
Actions an organism acquires through experience, observation, and interaction with the environment, rather than being genetically hardwired
Actions where individuals work together for a common goal, providing benefits to themselves and/or others
A behavior where one organism increases the reproductive fitness of another at a cost to its own fitness
A theory explaining altruistic behavior toward relatives, where individuals sacrifice their own survival and reproduction to help relatives survive and reproduce, increasing their shared genes
